level.heading: Negligent homicide.
level.text: Any person who, by the operation of any vehicle in a careless, reckless, or negligent manner, but not wilfully or wantonly, shall cause the death of another, including a pedestrian in a marked crosswalk, or unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, shall be guilty of a felony, and shall be punished by imprisonment for not more than 5 years or by a fine of not more than the amount set forth in § 22-3571.01 or both.

level.heading: Cross References
level.text: Traffic adjudication, violations prosecuted as criminal offenses, see § 50-2302.02.

level.heading: Effect of Amendments
level.text: The 2013 amendment by D.C. Law 19-317 substituted "of not more than the amount set forth in § 22-3571.01" for "of not more than $5,000".

level.heading: Emergency Legislation
level.text: For temporary (90 days) amendment of this section, see § 274 of the Criminal Fine Proportionality Emergency Act of 2013 (D.C. Act 20-45, April 1, 2013, 60 DCR 5400, 20 DCSTAT 1300).

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 4-145
level.text: For legislative history of D.C. Law 4-145, see Historical and Statutory Notes following § 50-2201.03.

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 4-174
level.text: Law 4-174 was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 4-398, which was referred to the Committee on Housing and Economic Development. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on October 19, 1982, and November 16, 1982, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on December 8, 1982, it was assigned Act No. 4-257 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review.

level.heading: Editor's Notes
level.text: Applicability of D.C. Law 19-317: Section 401 of D.C. Law 19-317 provided that the act shall apply only to offenses committed on or after June 11, 2013.
